sa259:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying in the Kalandaka’s Bamboo Park of Rājagṛha.
sa259:1.3: At the time, the Venerable Śāriputra and Mahākauṣṭhila was present on Mount Gṛdhrakūṭa.
sa259:2.1: In the afternoon, Mahākauṣṭhila got up from meditation and visited Śāriputra.
sa259:2.2: They exchanged greetings and pleasantries, and then he sat to one side.
sa259:3.2: “Sir, I would like to ask a question. Would you have a moment to answer it?”
sa259:4.2: “Sir, you may ask. I’ll answer with that I know.”
sa259:5.2: “If a monk who has yet to attain direct realization wishes to pursue direct realization, what method does he pursue?
sa259:6.2: “If a monk who has yet to attain direct realization wants to pursue direct realization, he diligently contemplates this:
sa259:6.3: ‘The five acquired aggregates are like illnesses, abscesses, thorns, and killers.
sa259:6.4: They are impermanent, painful, empty, and not self.’
sa259:6.6: Because it’s appropriate for his situation.
sa259:6.7: If a monk diligently contemplates these five acquired aggregates, he’ll realize the fruit of stream entry.”
sa259:7.2: “Śāriputra, suppose he wants to realize the fruit of once-returning after realizing the fruit of stream entry.
sa259:8.2: “Kauṣṭhila, someone who wants to realize the fruit of once-returning after realizing the fruit of stream entry should also diligently contemplate this,
sa259:8.3: ‘The five acquired aggregates are like illnesses, abscesses, thorns, and killers.
sa259:8.4: They are impermanent, painful, empty, and not self.’
sa259:8.6: Because it’s appropriate for his situation.
sa259:8.7: If a monk diligently contemplates these five acquired aggregates, he’ll realize the fruit of once-returning.”
sa259:9.2: “Suppose he wants to realize the fruit of non-returning after realizing the fruit of the once-returning.
sa259:10.2: “Kauṣṭhila, someone who wants to realize the fruit of non-returning after realizing the fruit of once-returning should also diligently contemplate this,
sa259:10.3: ‘The five acquired aggregates are like illnesses, abscesses, thorns, and killers.
sa259:10.4: They are impermanent, painful, empty, and not self.’
sa259:10.6: Because it’s appropriate for his situation.
sa259:10.7: If a monk diligently contemplates [65c] these five acquired aggregates, he’ll realize the fruit of non-returning.”
sa259:11.2: “Suppose he wants to realize the fruit of the arhat after realizing the fruit of non-returning.
sa259:12.2: “Kauṣṭhila, someone who wants to realize the fruit of the arhat after realizing the fruit of non-returning should also diligently contemplate this,
sa259:12.3: ‘The five acquired aggregates are like illnesses, abscesses, thorns, and killers.
sa259:12.4: They are impermanent, painful, empty, and not self.’
sa259:12.6: Because it’s appropriate for his situation.
sa259:12.7: If a monk diligently contemplates these five acquired aggregates, he’ll realize the fruit of the arhat.”
sa259:13.2: “After he attains fruit of the arhat, then what teaching does he contemplate?”
sa259:14.3: ‘The five acquired aggregates are illnesses, abscesses, thorns, and killers.
sa259:14.4: They are impermanent, painful, empty, and not self.’
sa259:14.6: Because he has attained what was yet to be attained, realized what was yet to be realized, and sees the teaching’s abode of happiness.”
sa259:15.1: Those two upright men each heard what was taught, rejoiced, and departed.
